editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE SCOTS FIGGARIES: OR, A Knot of Knaves. A Comedy.
LONDON, Printed by W. H. for Iohn Tey, at the White-Lion in the Strand, near the New Exchange, 1652.

div.head: To the Choise hand of Approved Gallantry, ROBERT DORMER Esq
div.p: THis Vessell, with her small Freight (not despairing of other Harbour) moves to put in to the Haven of your favour; The Greatest Tempest she rides under, is the Owners feares, which one benigne Beame from you Calmes and Disperses: Acceptance Dignifies the Adventure, and Crowns his Endeavours; who, yet a stranger, is Ambitious to be Endennized (with Pardon, and Permission.)

list.head: The Persons.
list.item:
Trapheire.
Pinckcarcase.
Townshift.
Drawforth. Blades of the Times.

sp.speaker: Iocky.
sp.p: A Sirs thes eyr has a mickle geod savour. Iha creept thus firr intolth' Kingdom, like an Erivigg intoll a mons lug, and sall as herdly be gat oout. Ise sa seff here as a Sperrow under a Penthoowse. Let the Sheriffo Cumberlond gee hang himsell ins own gartropts, Ise ferr enough off him, ans fellow Officer th' hangman noow. I a Scot Theff may pass for a trow Mon here; Aw the empty Weomb and thin hide I full oft bore in Scotland, an the geod fare I get here! Be me saw Ise twa yards gron about sin I cam fro Scotlond, the Deele split me gif I cam at thee mere Scotlond. Ise eene noow ny the bonny Court, wur meny a Scot lad is gron fro a Maggot ta a bran Goose; marry Ise in geod pleight. Weele, Scotlond, weele, tow gaff st me a mouth, but Anglond mon find me met; 'tis a geod soile geod feith, an gif aw my Contremon wod plant here, th'od thrive better thon in thair non. [Enter Billy. In the foule Deels name wha's yon? a sud be me Contremon by's scratin an scrubbin; A leokes like Scotlond it sell, bar an naked; A carries noought bet tha walth o Can aboot him, filth an Virmin.

sp.speaker: Billy.
sp.p:
Aw Scotlond, Scotlond, wa worth tha tim I cam oout o thee; Ise like tha wandering Jew ha worn my hoofes sa thin as pauper,
and can get ne shod for um; Anglond has geod sooft grond, bet tha peple ha mickle hard hearts; Aw Billy, Billy, th'adst better ha tane tha stripe for stelling in Scotlond (bet thot 'tis sin ta rob the spettle) an ha thriv'd by't, than ta come ta be hangd here, or stervd; tis keen Justace a mon sud dee sick a deeth for macking use o his hands, I ha ne oder mamber woorth ought.

sp.speaker: Iock;
sp.p: On's mon what gar thee in these pickle? how camst hither?

sp.speaker: Billy.
sp.p: Een on me ten toes sir, and thay err worn oout now, thay'l ser me ne longer.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Wha tha Deele sall mend'um? sham faw thee, a Scot an cannot shift.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: A lack sir, a mon mo not stell here for's neck, and Ise mickle sham ta beg.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: How mon not bag! Ons th'art nen a me Contremon than.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Ey marry that am I, geod feith Ise a Scot, an boorn at Andra keddin.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: I thoought fa be thy iddle leife, what gar thee cam hither?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: A lack mon I sud a bein whopt aboot tha Toown o Barwick for theiffing in Scotlond, bet brock gale and scapt it.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Hadst tow tha conscienc ta stell fro thy own Contre, an hast noot tha sece ta bag in an oder? fy mon, fy. Ons hoow thinkst leive? Leoke her mon, leok her, sa tha vertu o bagging [opens his Wallet and shews him meat. A sir d'yee drop, d'yee drop at mooth sir?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Ey sir, sike a seight may mack a mon sown.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Sow up your chops in tha Deeles nam, gif you cannot bag ye sall not eat sir.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Geod feith an I ha noot eat un morsell thes twa daies, cam awey mod, cam awey.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Nee, nee, sir stey your fercnes, keep your fangs off sir, yee ma ha tha mang.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Ne geod feith, Ise a clere skind lad.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Bet monstrous lozy.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Dooubt not that sir, thay'l pin ta death sir, for I ha noought ta fed 'um bet Sken, an that's twa toough for thair teth—cam awey mon, sum cherete good Contremon.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Weele set doowne—leoke thee here mon, [they sit down to eat. thes gis tha leg o a Anglish Prest.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Sey yee sa mon.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p:
Reight weele thay bein mad up o Cappon and whit broth▪ thay mack their carcase fat, bet their folls len; d'yee thenk S. Andra wad a fe • ted la mickle gif a cud a gat sike met as thes▪ Ne, ne, by me saw Ise hang than; he was stervd, thay fare deliciously; he wos
• oowzy, and hod no sheft, they bien buried aleife in fin lenin an lown sleeffes▪
• he stunk abo grond, they bien swetten'd leiving an deed, abo an under gron; A me saw S. Andra had her don sa meny marvailes gif a h • d stuft his carcase la full as thay.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Geod feith I main pass for a sent ten, for me carcase is bar an thin enough.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Ey for sent Theff, for he ner did mirackle—thes Torky leg cam fro a Merchants Table, thes Widgins wing fro a Citzens, an thes Gooses leg fro a Lawyers.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Bred, thay mack mere preambl 'boot thair boody then aw tha peple in Cristendum de aboot thair saws, how hadst tow tha fece ta speeke at sa meny dores mon?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: A sir, I sall tach yee ta bag bravely, mind ye me noow sir, I stoll twa Coows fro me Contremon and gat tham agat ta Comberlond ta seele, bet tha plaggy shriefe gar tham tack fro me, an sent me toll tha gale, bet I gat loose, an sa cam froward, an in tha Noorth I met a iddle Turnies lod, wha mad me thes Certifice, an sat aw those Jestece nams tol't, that tha shreife o Comberlond had den me mickle wrong, an sa Ise cam up toll th' King for Jestece.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Geod feith wad I had sike an oder.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Cam awey mon, hest thee, fill thy weomb, and get thee on you sid mon, an Ise kep o thes, and sa nen fall scap us—hark ye me mon, you mon tell 'am you cam o geod parentage, an ha lost aw your siller as ye cam for Anglond—you mon speeke a by mon, an noot lick a Mole under gron pest herring.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Weele, weele, Ile be avis'd be you, gif you far weele I fall noot far amiss.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Gang awey mon, gang awey mon, seest tow, seest tow yon braw mon tofore thy eyne.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: —Bless your honor, Ise speeke a word or twa ta your honor.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: My honour▪—Pox on your fawning hide, what would you have with me and be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: —Ne, ne, sir I pray your honor wax noot wrothfull, Ise a mon o geod ranck in my own Contre, an ha kept geod beasts.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: I, for some bodies else, thou dost not look as though thou ere wert worth one.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Ne, ne, sir, me non proper geods geod feith; I cam wi mickle siller in me purss ta Englond, weele clad.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: With some old Curtaines that bore S. Andrews story, or childrens blanquets stoll, and turn'd to Trowsies.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Ne geod feith, I ha een bien robd o aw.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Rob thee! of what? had he a mind to be lowsie? but this is an Engine laid to draw a peece of silver to you, is't not so?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Your Honor speekes mickle weele.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: —There—there's some of your Countrey men at Court lives better by this trade than you.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Un word ta your honor.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Hy day, another! I'm way laid, hast thou been rob'd too?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Ne, ne sir, ne, tha shriffe o Comberlond has dun me mickle wrong sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Whipt you about the Pigmarket?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: A has tacken awey me Cows sir, an aw me geods, see here sir, I ha aw thos worthy Jestece nams ta testifie.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: There is no begger like the Scotch-beger for tricks and impudence—Come what must discharge me from you sir, and your bellowing?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Geod feith sir I wont siller ta gat Jestece.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: —Hadst thou had Justice done thee, thou hadst been hang'd long before this.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Bred, he's a fortune teller.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: There—that will serve to buy you Oatmeale; sir there is no more of your Catterwalling Companions here abouts, is there?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Ne, ne sir, ant lick your honor.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Ne, ne, pox on your Nees and your Nose too; I'm glad I'm rid on you.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Noow sir, ye had noot tha fece ta bag, hoow lick ye it noow sir, what ga he toll ye.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Thes smaw peece o siller.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: A geod begining mon, tolld a ye noot sum o our Contre men liev'd at Court by baggin.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: I sea noow a Scot may ly by atorete, an beg wi permission— weele to Curt ta, an ly sa fest as tha beest o'um.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Be me saw an thats herd ta dee; [Enter Mr Folly' seest tow, seest tow mon yon brawe fellow, wi't his gold Rop aboots neck, an's long Cot lick a sark, geod feith he's ta herd for twantyo'um.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: He's tha feul, gis a noot?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Ey, ey mon; A has feuld himsell intoll mickle fevor gif a feul himsell noot oout agen—sey a cams aneust us mon, wees speeke toll him—Bless your honor sir, bless your honor, Ise gled ta sea your honour in heelth.

sp.speaker: Folly,
sp.p: Be me saw th'art a bold fellow.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: I'm your own Contremon sir, I ken your honor mickle weele, bless your worship.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Kenst tow me mon?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Mickle weele an't lick your honour, I ken your honor weele enough, your honour is the Kings feul.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: A mon, he kepes mere feules than I; bred, he's kepe tow ta gif tow canst feul him; how far Scot art tow?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Marry Ise a mickle wey oofe noow.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Bet I wad kne what tow wert boorn.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Gin me Moders Weomb sir forty years agast.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Ons mon speeke toll me i what plece o Scotlond wert tow boorn.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Geod feith gin meny sir, I ha bien boorn fro plece to plece a me Moders back sir, and ha seffered mickle sorrow.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: The fow Deele tack thy large lug, wha was thy fader?

sp.speaker: Ioc
sp.p: A mon sir surely.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: The black Deele a was sur, whar liev'd a▪

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: A sir at a plece your honour kens mickle weele.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Whar mon, whar?

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: A sir, A sir what pleice caw ye that sir whar your honor nurst tha tyny babe wi wull on's back sir?

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Oout tha faw Deele, oout Rog—bet wha art tow mon?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: I'm een yar Contremon twa sir, cam ta bien a Curtier ta sir.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Ons a Curtier! a Carter, tha Hangmon, that Deele.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Ye ha geod friends thar sir, ye may dee mickle for us.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Dee mon! bred, he that sall dee for thee sall ha enough ta dee; art geod for oought? wha canst dee for thy sell?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Een what ye sea sir.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Oout this is base, it shams your Contre, mind ye me; wha o ye swaine ha mest wot?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: He that can sheft beest.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Reight weele.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: And that's een I, this feule had noot a fece ta bag toll I boldend hum.

sp.speaker: Fol
sp.p: Oout, oout mon, sham feect?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Ne, ne. I sall grew bold enough gif I fall get oought by't.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Gif ye had Clad sirs, what curs wad ye tacke to liew?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Ise cud mack tha King, bliss his Worship, an't lick your honour, mickle geod Puttins an Potsloose.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: I'd bien oth Mint, sir, I loove ta finger siller.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Weele sirs cam away wy me, for Contres sack Ise gat ye sum Purveyance, an sum lodging, and tan we fall find oout lum woork for ye emong 'um here.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Bless your honor for your benefaites.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Pray recollect your self, I cannot do't
Without a loss to my repute and fame,
If you have but a foot of ground unsold.
Therefore consult your thoughts, my willingness
Shall not be wanting to procure your freedome;
But I'd not have a dirty peece of Land
Bring an obstruction to't.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Why? as I live
I have not an Inch left; what ere I morgag'd
Is either sold out-right, or forfeited,
I lie not on my Credit.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: How's that Man?
Have you credit then? Why, that's as bad.
It is not held convenient by the Huffe,
Lords of the sword, that any Yongster should
Be one of us 'till he 'as not only lost
his 'state, but's credit too.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Upon my life,
Deare Townshift, I've not credit for a thrips;
Thou knowst it well enough, my roaging Landres
Will not do't for the washing of a shirt.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Why, have you shirts then?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: One as I live, no more, and that so thin
You may draw't through a Needle.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: What Boots have you?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I cannot call these any, yet th'are all;
And as for stockings, I have long agoe
Held them unnecessary.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Why this Cloake,
And th' weather warm and friendly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'Tis too much,
The weight on't, I confess, 's not to be borne,
Ile ease me of the burthen, It shall sink
In sack when I'm made free, prethee about it.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: I would not for a world you should have any
Remnant of your Estate left,'t would undo you
See, here's my Brothers, Drawforth and Pinck-carkase
May I presume to recommend you to 'em?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You may, you may, deare Townshift.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: How now Trapheire,
What is all gon yet?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: All he sweares by's Twibell,
His Cloak excepted, and its time expires
Within this half houre; shall we make him free?

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.l: Trapheire, you now are to begin the World,
Which you cannot do handsomly, unless
Your Land and you be separated, and if
Ought ly conceal'd, 'twill rise in judgment 'gainst you;
Therefore pray have a care, 'tis Christian Counsell.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: It is not fit the least peece of your old
Adulterate fortunes should corrupt the new
Your wit must purchase.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Right, beside, he'l ne'r
Have a refin'd Wit 'till he has nothing left.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: The greatest Enemy I have Gentlemen is my Cloake,
And I promise Ile fee 't no more.

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.l: Say you so, then to the next Taverne;
Boy—boy—a Roome.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Please you to walke into a Roome Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: What call we thee for else?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: How like you this Roome Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Indifferent; bring us Wine and Tobacco of the best sirrah.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: You shall indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Deare Townshift thou must shew this Gentleman
The way to th' Brokers.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Is he for sale, or Morgage?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: For sale by all meanes, I'd not charge my memory
I've ought left worth redeeming.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Bravelie resolv'd—Is't Racie?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Right Racie sir beleeve me.

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.l: Trapheire to thee.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Drinke apace, deare Townshift
The sight of that same Gentleman's my tortour,
I prethee rid me of him.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Townshift sweare him.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I cann't with a safe conscience sweare as long
As that appeares before me.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: How shall I get it out oth' house?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Leave thine here, and weare mine thither.
O how I hate to call it mine—awaie wit't.

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.l: Trapheire, you now must exercise your Wit
To live on others, as w'ave liv'd on you;
Wit's never good till purchas'd, what though't be
With th' loss of fortunes Trumperie and Trash;
Content ne'r dwels 'mong dirtie Land, who sells it
Parts with a deale of care, and scurvie toile;
Men never are ingenious that are clog'd with't.
The Generous spirit will not be coop'd up
In that same Countrey Cage, a mansion house,
And confines of the Buttery; be free,
Thou art not worth a Groat
When this is spent.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: How much, how much deare Townshift?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: But thirtie by my Valour.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Down with't, down with't;
Ile not put up a Dodkin on't; deare Townshift,
Drinke, drinke away, I thirst untill it's melted,
Your moulten silver swallows best.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: His Oath, his Oath.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Your sword.
sp.stage: [Laies his hand on the Hilts of his Sword,
sp.l: By this Hilt, and this Blade
Which at Hounslow was made,
You sweare to be true
To what shall ensue.
sp.p: First, You sweare not to make it any scruple of Conscience to cheat your Father; That you will hunt after young Heires, and when you have courst them out of wind, you'l refresh 'em with some Scrivener, Broker, or Draper; That you'l keep alwaies three strings to your bow, to make it bend till it breake; That having gotten a Bubble or Byshop, a lad of the last adoption, that you make him sensible of a Wench, though to the charge of a Surgeon, it being reason all trades should live, and if occasion be, winke at small faults. Next be sure to keep them continually at Game, or Drinking; Uurge 'em to quarrell, and then take up the businesse, but not without profit to the Brotherhood; That what quarrels soever arise among our selves, must not cause us to fight with one another, but the Coines of the Bubble or Byshop must make us friends; That you must not pay your Coachman but with kicks, unlesse your Bubble or Byshop do, and then he owes you a fare; That your Bubble, or Byshop, and you, keep but one Purse, though two Drabs; That when you have dreined him dry, you make him free, if he sue for it, if not let him keep Company with the Titteretues, and live upon the sin of Sodom; That you I take your chance of the day, where there is need of dipping, without grumbling.
sp.l: That while you can stand
With sword in your hand,
You'l not be in aw
Of the Halberteere Law;
Kiss this—Now y'are free
Of the Huffs company.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Hey for the Brotherhood; No Wine stirring, Boy? You Rascal, where's your duty? absent? hah! More Wine.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: You shall sir by and by.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Bring a Glass will hold
A Pint at least, I hate a thimble full,
We shall ne'r have consum'd this mighty mass
If we sip thus like sparrows;
I marry, this looks like some Brother to you all.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Gramercy.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Sirrah, cover the Boord with Bottles,
This is our Coronation day, the Room
Shall swim in Wine; be frolique Huffs, and draine
Me dry, yet I shall live when y'are all hang'd.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: How now, how now Traphiere!

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Drink and be damn'd;
Must I waite on your Driveling?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Drawforth to you—Charge him home.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Traphiere a whole bottle to thee—I'm up toth' Chin.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: —So, so sir,—y'are a fine fellow; Is all paid?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: No, all's not come in yet.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Ile stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Pray leave my cloak behind you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Your cloak sir? how came it to be yours sir? I have one some where.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Yours is at the Brokers sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Is it so sir? I thank you for your information.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: There lies the vertue on't.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: So sir, I thanke you twice; for once I care not if I put my Cloak into my pocket.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: But Trapheire, Trapheire.

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.l: Who paies the house?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Let the house pay it selfe; dip, dip and be hang'd you that have Cloaks, am I bound to fill your insatiate Gorge eternally.

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.p: What Asses were we to let the mony ly so long, knowing his Rascally humour, he'l not pay a Penny when he's in drink— See what thou canst work him to.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Boy.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Sir—I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Trapheire, a prize Trapheire.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Of what? Sprats?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: A Gudgin man, a Gudgin's come to Net;
The Master of the house desires admittance
To play a Game at Ticktack for a Peece;
And thou knowst Trapheire—hah—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I know it Rogue;
And thou shalt play with him for all he's worth;
Ile venture on thy hand my whole Estate,
This my trusty Blade. Provided alwaies sir—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: That you have half—'tis granted—he's here;
Thou knowst I have no money.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Thou shalt not want deare Bully, Ile not leave
My selfe a George.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Spoke like thy selfe, come be so.
There sir, pay your self.

sp.speaker: Mr,
sp.l: Y'are kindly welcome Gentlemen, fetch my Quart.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Death, what's this?

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Ha ha, ha—Only the Reckoning paid sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Y'are Rogues, Shirks, and Cheates; Ile indict you

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.l: Buoy good sir, imploy your Tongue at Billings gate;
Adieu, adieu.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Farewell and be hang'd.
sp.p: For your part sirrah, Ile have you up for keeping of a Bawdy house.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Do your worst sir, do your worst.

div.head: ACT. II.
div.stage: Enter Folly, Iocky, and Billy, very Gallant.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Y'ar mickle braw sirs, y'ar mickle braw; bred, ye leoke mere lick Burgemasters noow thon hedg creepers; ken ye your sells sirs? ken ye your sells sirs?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Geod feith sir, gif aw that sud ken themsells, wad ken themsells, nen wad ken us; A me saw sir, I'd rader ha'um trast me thon ken me, fur gif thay sudken me reight, thay'd sea me deed tofore thay' trast me.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Y'ar mickle wise sir, ye ha rob'd a feul sur.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: We wish you weele sir, we wish you weele.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Sey ye sa sir? y'ar vary cheretable; ken ye me sirs? On's, ye are gron see loofty you'l knee ne body; wha set you up in tha Deeles nam? wha, wha put thes gay fethers on your back? eene I, an noow yol flee awey ta tha Deele, Harke ye me sirs, gif ye bien sa high, Ise tack ye down wy a Plague ta ye; wha had y'ar intail'd Virmine tane off ye wy a murren? wha, wha gat ye a—

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Oour saders and moders sir.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Did thay sa sir? bred, gif thay gat ye, thay ner cud gat feod enough for yar side Weombs; Are you provander prickt noow sirs? ha, wha am I? ha sirs, ha, wha am I?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: O our geod friend sir, blisse you.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: The Deele wound ye, sleight ye me? On's, Ise sa geod a mon gas aw in Scotlond, an ha mere siller in me purse.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Anglish stamp sir, I beleev't.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Ye beleeft! wha tha Deele cares for your beleeff?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Geod sir, geod sir be sober.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Bred, Ise not drunken; ha ye bien at cost wy me sirs? hah! Ise sall uncass ye sirs, an ge your Arse tha Ayre agen, are ye sa hot sirs? want ye a Cooler? Bred, Ise ge ye sick a Rattle wy a Rom ore tha Riggins sall mack your Ribs reore sirs.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Geod your honor put up your wroth, an wees buckle oour Wots; wees yar on Contremons ye knee weele enough.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: An sud leove won oder; y'ave a geod Mester sir, an oour Contremon, wha macks mickle o you.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Bred, an Ise mack sa mickle o hum as I can.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: He's a geod mon sir, and you ha wot enough.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Ken you that mon, ken you that? On's, an ye bien not wud ye ma ha wot ta chep enough; bet Ise ne body, my benefaits are noought woorth.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Y'ar aw body sir, wees at your Commandement.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Sey ye sa sir? why, noow ye speeke, be vis'd by me, anye sall oout wot 'um aw; mind ye me sirs, will ye be avis'd?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Sed ye sir, wy aw our harts.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Ise ha ye turn Dooctors.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Ise a Dooctor, a Dooctor; geod feith, wees mack braw Dooctors.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Mind me mon, mind me; Thes Kingdom's mickle sick, tha Curt o tha Cety, tha Cety o tha Curt, an tha Contre o beoth, an aw o' • m o tha Kirke, an tha Law; tha Kingdom's Livergron wy iddlnes an Raches, and noow noought can cur it bet a Scots Dooctor, ne matter for your skill.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Geod feith sir, wees ha skill enough ta bleede its siller vains Ise warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Ha bet confidence, lye and dissemble handsomly.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Wees y'ar on Contremons sir, doobt it noot.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Tha nam o a Scot gis enough ta cur aw their maladies; ge 'um peson an thay'l tack it for a Cordall: perswad 'um thay ar sick thay'l beleeff ye, and gif ye mack 'um sick thay'l beleeff thare in beest helth, bet ye mon carry sem show o hollines wy ye, an profess aw for thayr geods.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Sa we sall sir, an tack'um whan we ha deon.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Billy sall gaing toll th' Contre, and tow salt kep behind, an bien Dooctor here, and gif tow hest wot enough tow canst noot wont werk.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Ne geod feith, I sall mack me sell werk enoough, for gif I can hel ne distampers Ise mack enoough emong 'um.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Cam awey than, cam awey.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: —'Twas Morning ere he went to bed sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: —All's one; tell who 'tis, and 'twill be warrant
Enough for your awaking him; 'tis business
I come about, and of concernment too,
That cannot admit delay.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Ile venture then to call him sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Do so—if this designe
Of mine prove prosperous, Townshift, it will be
Some comfort to me that I am even with thee.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: He'l waite upon you presently,
He's rising.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: A good Lad—Townshift arme thy selfe, for I am prepar'd
To give thee an assault, and dare thy Action
At Law, if Wit and Sword should faile,
Deare Townshift.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: By this light I have not slept
A minute; what's the news? you serv'd us bravely the other night at Taverne.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: On this drinking!
This perillous Drinking will destroy us all;
Thy pardon my deare heart, the business now
I come about will try thy friendship.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: How?
I hope no quarrell.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yes, with my base stars.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: But what's the matter, tell me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That's my meaning,
A sort of Rascally Bailiffes dog'd me hither,
And thou knowst if I be once ta'ne I am
A slave perpetually.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: What wouldst thou have me to do?
Wee'l send to Drawforth and the rest.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'T won't do,
They'l make but a disturbance in the street,
Yet I may be surpriz'd for all their Valour,
And then I am undone; the hopes I have
In one I am to dine with lost, which might
Be worth to thee and me some hundreds Bully.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Send for him, now let him take up the business.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What, ere I'm throughly known to him; besides,
Should he take this up twenty more would follow't,
Who knowing me so low now, do forbeare
To execute their rigour.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: What wouldst have me do?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Harke thee, I've thought upon a fine Deceit;
Hast any Patches in thy Chamber?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Rare ones,
Of all sorts.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: One to Disguise my face, with a Cloake, would
Do't to the life.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Sure they are gon, Ile send to see.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Oh hang 'em Rogues, th' are sculking at th' Lanes end,
Or some blind Alenouse—Dearest Townshift do't.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Do what?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Lend me thy Cloake, and Ile contrive a Patch
Shall cover my left eye, they may not know me.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: I know not what to do—I should go forth
My selfe.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Nay prethee Townshift—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Will you leave
Your Sword then▪ you'l have no—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Prethee wouldst have me
Pass by 'em unprovided, put the worst,
They should descry me.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: There's no trick in't Trapheire?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: No more trick than you see; I prethee meet me in Fishstreet at the Feathers, where wee'l dine; there thou shalt see my friend, and Ile restore thy Cloake deare Townshift.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Well, thou shalt ha't—Boy fetch
My Cloake and patches—'tis thine, there take it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Gramercy; Is't hansome?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Very well; I must lie down and take a Nap at twelve;
I will not faile to meet thee.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Sirrah boy, be sure you wake him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I warrant you sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha,
I'm sworne to cheat my father, and 'tis fit
He that first made the Gin should hansell it.

sp.speaker: Smal.
sp.l: —Sir, you are kindly welcome, and the oftner
You visit me, the welcommer you shall be;
I honor men of knowledge. Master Folly,
I am oblig'd to you for his acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: —Geod feith sir, an he's worth yours; I sall play him wy any Anglish Dooctor in the VVarld.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Ne sir, Ise can dee mere than Ise speeke sir.

sp.speaker: Smal.
sp.l: —I beleeve you sir,
By what I find of truth within my selfe;
I must confess, I am not altogether
So right as I would, my body tels me
I may admit of Physick.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Mickle weele sir.

sp.speaker: Smal.
sp.l: I'm troubled with the Spleene, a strong disease
Amongst ns Magistrates, which makes me feare
'Tis not for cure.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Ise cur it in twa minutes gif ye ha
Bien trobl'd wy it twanty years, an aw
Your tribe gif tha' • cam toll me.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.l: Ne, ne, he's reight.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: You'l do a wondrous cure then.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: I sall dee' to me honor; bet that's noot aw
Your Malade, ye are noot soound at heart sirs.

sp.speaker: Smal.
sp.l: I know not that sir.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Planty an iddleness ha bred gross humours in you, whilke mon be pourged awey, or elke ye dee for't; bet Ise sall ge ye that sir, sall mack ye bare an leight enough.

sp.speaker: Smal.
sp.l: I thank you sir; accept this, pray, and I
Shall further gratifie, but be speedy,
Good sir, with your Preparatives.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Ise gang aboot it stret, Ise gang aboot it sir.

sp.speaker: Smal.
sp.l: Your servant Gentlemen, I shall heare from you sir.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Soone, mickle soone sir;
sp.p: Leoke mon, leoke aw thay bien sick o gis sike fin things as thes, fiev golden lads mon, fiev mere are woorth a Leards land sir; geod feith gif their veynes wul ran sike droops as thes wees drain um dry—A simple feuls, that ken noot whan th'are weele, bet wull bien wasting thair means toll set thair boodies oout o frame—a feuls, feuls.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Ne matter mon gif oought can be gut wy putting um oout o fram, tha Deele try his skill to put um in agen for Iocky.

div.stage: Enter Billy, and a Crew of Country People.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Kepe off firs—kepe off, ga me wund toll speeke toll ye; Ise cam for aw your geods, mind ye me?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Very well, very well.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Ise cur aw diseases, aw manner o Malades, an sall tack noought o ye for me peyn bet your siller; Gif there bien er a Kirke Prest emong ye choak'd up wy Pluraltes o Benefaits, tha Poowder in thes pauper macks the Impostom breck, an tacks aw awey clere—Gif any Prest bien vext wy tha Babylonish mang, thes Purgation med in me non Contre, curs hum were he ner sa fer spent.

sp.speaker: 1 Coun.
sp.p: For our Doctor sir, for our Doctor.

sp.speaker: 2 Coun.
sp.p: For our Vicar.

sp.speaker: 3 Coun.
sp.p: For our Parson.

sp.speaker: 4 Coun.
sp.p: For our Curat.

sp.speaker: 5 Coun.
sp.p: For our Bishop, Prebends, and Curates.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Gif any emong ye bien troubl'd wy tha neyce o Organs in your lugs, thes poowder curs you for ever.

sp.speaker: 1 Co.
sp.p: For our Town sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Co.
sp.p: For ours too sir.

sp.speaker: 3 Co.
sp.p: And ours, and ours sir.

sp.speaker: 4 Co.
sp.p: And our whole County sir.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Gif eny emong ye bien blind wy tha seight o Lawn sleeves, thes cures and restores ye.

sp.speaker: 1 Co.
sp.p: For my Landlord sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Co.
sp.p: For mine too sir.

sp.speaker: 3 Co.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: 4 Co.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: 5 Co.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Gif eny emong ye ha tha beon o a tith'd Soows babey stick in your wund pip, thes saw cur you stret, and tack aw awey.

sp.speaker: 1 Co.
sp.p: For me sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Co.
sp.p: For me too sir.

sp.speaker: 3 Co.
sp.p: And me sir.

sp.speaker: 4 Co.
sp.p: And me sir.

sp.speaker: 5 Co.
sp.p: And me sir pray.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Gif eny emong ye bien troubl'd wy heart burnings, tha Poowder in thes pauper curs ye stret.

sp.speaker: 1 Co.
sp.p: For my Neighbour sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Co.
sp.p: And mine sir.

sp.speaker: 3 Co.
sp.p: And mine too sir, I pray.

sp.speaker: 4 Co.
sp.p: And som for our whole Town good sir.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Gif eny o ye bien sore wy ore mickle burdens, an weary o your Riders, thes Poowder macks ye strong ta orethraw um, or ta bar greater.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: For us all sir.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Gif eny o your stomacks bien opprest wy Law, thes pell sall remoove tha cause, an tack it awey. Gif eny bien hard boound, thes sall mack mickle free.

sp.speaker: 1 Co.
sp.p: For my Landlord sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Co.
sp.p: For mine too sir

sp.speaker: 3 Co.
sp.p: And mine sir.

sp.speaker: 4 Co.
sp.p: And mine sir.

sp.speaker: 5 Co.
sp.p: And mine sir.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Gif eny emong ye bien trobl'd wy a scurvy mooth, thes tacks aw felth awey.

sp.speaker: 1 Co.
sp.p: For my wife sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Co.
sp.p: For mine sir.

sp.speaker: 3 Co.
sp.p: And mine sir.

sp.speaker: 4 Co.
sp.p: And mine sir.

sp.speaker: 5 Co.
sp.p: And my Mistresse sir.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Gif eny bien trobl'd wy a loosnes, thes ties 'um fest as a Rope or hawter.

sp.speaker: 1 Co.
sp.p: For my wife sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Co.
sp.p: And mine sir.

sp.speaker: 3 Co.
sp.p: And mine sir.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Geod Peple, noow I ha gau ye aw remedies ta your Malades, twa dees hence Ise sall bien her or noot ta sey whot operation thay ha had upon ye; Ise sur ye sall ha remedy or non; an sa far ye wall.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Farewell sir, farewell.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A pretty place this.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: But the Company!
The Company dear Coz hither resorts
Gives life and sweetnes to't; the rarest wits!
So rare la man may lose himselfe ere he
Discover 'em—for they are not to be—
Discovered—Besides, the Women, Ladies,
Of such excelling beauty, you would sweare
They painted—and not be forsworne, as merry
As Cupid when he wantons.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And you spent
Your meanes amongst 'um?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And spent rarely well!
I've no remorce for't. Can you sing?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Not I Coz.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: How Coz? not sing! why then you are no Company;
We have a merry life so long as't lasts.
Ile lay my life you fence not neither.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Yes,
My grounds I do.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Have you the grounds of fencing? that is, to
Make the Passado, to retreive, comply,
Defend, make up, close, and Disarme;
You know not this I warrant?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Not I truly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I cannot think what will become of you,
When you meet Men of valour.

sp.speaker: Witw.
sp.l: I pray keep me
Out of their company, I love no quarrels;
I came to study th' Law.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: At a fine time.
Y'ave bought no Books I hope.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: I, but I have.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Returne them to the Bookseller for shame;
A Sword will prove more usefull: hark ye Coz,
I am resolv'd to have you learn to fence.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: I'd rather learn to sing.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That ye shall too:
Your money will do all things—yonder's Townshift,
How like a Rogue he looks? I will not shun him.
And Cozen, as I was telling you

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: With your leave sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'Twas well askt sir,
What's your will with me?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: My Cloak sir—wher's my Cloak sir?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Even at the Brokers sir—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: How—you are a Rogue.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That's nothing sir—your railing will not fetch it out agen.
Townshift I love thee, thou knowst I doe.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: A pox upon you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Thou knowst the oath, I'm not to spare my Father.
And though we quarrell, yet we must not fight.
I'm punctuall to my Oath; but if thou hast
The conscience, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Is he sunk for ever.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No, it may rise again, if you be civil.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Is that your friend?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And Kinsman.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Wilt thou cheat him too?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: My Oath is past, I will not be forsworn
For a Kings ransom.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Nay then, I'm satisfied.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Come, be known to him—Coz, this is my friend.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Sir, I kisse your hand.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: I thank you heartily sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Fie Coz, fie, there's a complement.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: He does not look as though he needed ought,
Save what thou wantst, a Cloak.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Good wit Coz, good wit.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Oh Rogue, how he claws him.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Where shall's dine?

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: I'le to the Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: In Fetter-lane.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: To feed on Bruis, and be serv'd with Linnen
As sable as the chimney. No, weel take
A Coach, and hence to Fish-street.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: What shall we do there?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Eat fish, the World does not afford the like.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: But th' Coach is costly,

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Pough, I'l be at that;
'Tis said the Milk of Asses, makes men fat.

div.head: ACT. III.

sp.speaker: Iock.
sp.p: FY Mastres fy, geod feith y'ar mickle oout; I ga hum noought bet convenable stooff.

sp.speaker: Mrs Small.
sp.p: Y'are a Rascall, a Scotch Horseleech, a Doctor, a Dolthead: Oh the madness of the men of these times; if any of them be but a little out of temper, none can set them right but a Scotch Doctor forsooth, as though all the English ones were fooles. But Sirrah, Sirrah, it is well known my husband [she runnes at him. was never distempered, till he came acquainted with such a De-coy as you—Curse on the time—

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Geod Mistras hark ye toll me.

sp.speaker: Mrs Small.
sp.p: Hang you Rascall, my Husband was never troubled with whimsies in his head, nor never rail'd against his Superiours; he was ever a quiet man, and an honest man, and had the love of the whole Court, and so had I too. Many a good turn have the good Gentlemen done me, which I must never expect now agen, so violently my Husband railes against the Government. But if he suffer for't, thou shalt not weare a Nose to thy face; a Nose on thy face said I: Nay if there bee a sign-post in all this Town I'l hang thee on't— Ah poor heart.
Here hee comes—See what a pickle you have put him in; My fingers itch to come at thy face, that ugly [she runs at him. face of thine.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: A me saw shee's a Deele, and wull spell aw my Market gif I ser her noot lick him; thes gis o tha sem powder, whilke gif sha smell ta, wull mack her sa lick him as may be.

sp.speaker: Mrs Small.
sp.l: Sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Mr Small.
sp.l: Oh, art thou there? tis well; there has bin nere
A Pursevant here yet to fetch me, has there?

sp.speaker: Mrs Small.
sp.l: A Pursevant for you! for what cause Husband?

sp.speaker: Mr Small.
sp.l: I am too honest, that is cause enough.
There is a Councell Table, Yes forsooth,
And at it is contriv'd mens ruines—hah.
Who's that? who's that? ist not for me they ask?
I shall be lost quite, if I look not well
About me.

sp.speaker: Mrs Sma.
sp.l: True, y'are in the way to undo
Your selfe, and me, and all your Family.
But this is thy Gin Rascall; Oh I could tear thee.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Mistras ga me whil toll speeke toll ye; thes wudnes o his, cam fro tha corruption o his hart: Aw that I ga hum was sike as thes, be me saw smeel Laddy, smeel Laddy.

sp.speaker: Mrs Small.
sp.l: I have not Patience.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Ne, ne, be noot wud, smeel toll it.

sp.speaker: Mrs Small.
sp.l: My thinks tis very comfortable.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Hoow doll ye geod sir?

sp.speaker: Mr Small.
sp.l: Oh Mr Doctor is't thee! art safe?
'Tis wonderfull there's nothing charg'd against thee!
There is an Office call'd the Green-cloth too,
Has no man had thee there yet?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: They ken me sa weel sir—It warks brawly.

sp.speaker: Mrs Small.
sp.p: Hark you Husband, what is that you said but now? I beleev't, what was't? the King is pestilent, wilfull; hah; I was't so? why then, for ought I know, hee must bee beaten into better manners.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Reight weel sed geod feith.

sp.speaker: Mrs Small.
sp.l: Honest Mr Doctor, pray come in sir;
You are the welcom'st man come to my house
This fortnight—Husband love him, has he not
A taking countenance?

sp.speaker: Mr Small.
sp.l: No body at the Gate?
I am possest with feares and jealousies.

sp.speaker: Mrs Small.
sp.l: And well you may be Husband, I am sure
You have had cause enough, good Man, I grieve,
I grieve to think on't.

sp.speaker: Mr Small.
sp.l: Mr Doctor, be advis'd;
Pray go not unprepar'd; to Night you shall
Take my house for your shelter, things work strangely.

sp.speaker: Mrs Small.
sp.l: Sweet Mr Doctor you shall be so welcome,
It passes; truly, y'are a man upright
In every thing I warrant, pray come in sir.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Geod feith, tha cass is awter'd.

div.stage: Enter a Crue of Countrey People.

sp.speaker: 1 Coun.
sp.p: Bring forth your Prongs Neighbours; All men stand up for the truth: And he that will lie on the Sunday, is not to be trusted the week after, what say you Neighbours?
I say a Sundaies lie may go as far as a work-daies, my reason is, it has more leasure to travell.
For my part neighbours let them lie that will I have no more to doe with a lie, then a lie has to do with me; if any lies with my wife, it shall go hard but ile do as much with his.
I, if he have none Neighbour.
Why, if he have none Neighbour, I must go without; no man will be a slave I think.

A slave! who has such a mind let him have it still: For my part Neighbours, Ile worke hard, earn my bread with the sweat of my browes, none shall eat away the fruit of my labour, but I will sit down when it is done, and laugh, in despight of all the Kasars in the World.
What! have wee a scab'd sheep amongst us? lets cleere our flock of him.
Hold Neighbour, hold, I am for you with all my heart, but give me leave to speak to you; I am but a fool 'tis confest, but children and fooles tell truth sometimes, you know.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: And what of that, and what of that.

I say again, 'tis dangerous medling with edge-tooles; there's store of trees here abouts, and there may bee Gibbets made of them, and you know well enough what fruit Gibbets bring forth; I say no more, but be carefull what you do.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Away with him, away with him.
One word more Neighbours, one word more; it is not well to mocke our Superiours, much worse to threaten them: for as I have heard, there was a suit at Law commenced about a Fart.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, how man, how!

Why, I will tell you Neighbours, be but patient; there was a fellow, Ile not tell his name, was pissing against the wall, the Mayor came by, now you know the Proverb, tell a tale to a Mare, and 'twill let a fart; but here the case alters, for the fellow let the fart, and the Mayor took it in the nose, and caused the fellow to bee carried to the Town Hall, as Prisoner.
The Mayor was a Horse, or a Whorson knave, what's this to us?

sp.l: Now toth' suit.
'Tis worn out, weel have none on't.
Neighbours lay down your Prongs, take my devise;
'Tis an old Proverb, be merry and wise.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Away with him, away with him, we will break the Cords of our slavery.

div.stage: Enter Iocky, and Folly, and Anything.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.l: Thes gis tha Doctor, I toll'd ye o sir, mickle wise an holy,
My non Contrymon ta sir.

sp.speaker: Any.
sp.l: Sir the Character
The Town receives of you, makes me ambitious
Of your Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Iock.
sp.l: I complamen noot sir, Ise doown reight Scot;
Aw verety an honesty.

sp.speaker: Any.
sp.l: The better sir.
That language is the freest from deceit,
That carries most simplicity.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Ne, ne, Ise noot sa sample neder.

sp.speaker: Any.
sp.l: Pardon me;
I speak not in that sense, but have regard
Unto the Metaphor; I don't conclude,
'Cause th' Organ of the soule may be infected,
The soul must be imperfect; for I've known
Men rarely endu'd, that Nature has deny'd
The benefit of expression to.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Y'ar a Scollard sir.

sp.speaker: Any.
sp.l: And I presume you one. I have read something
Of th' Metaphysicks, though I took not on me
The function, or the practice: But, no more
Of that sir, 'tis not wisdome in a man
Unskil'd, to hold a weapon against a Fencer.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Mickle weel sed geod feith.

sp.speaker: Any.
sp.l: All my Discourse
Drawes to this Period; that is, you'd be pleased
T'afford me your opinion; some thing I aile,
But know not what, save this, a deprivation
Of breath, and find it prejudiciall to
My Calling.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: You ha bad lungs sir, whilk macks ye short wound.

sp.speaker: Any.
sp.l: I could have told you that sir; My defect
Proceeds from thence; but for the Remedy—
I know my failings.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: You'l faw sir intoll a Consumption very soon sir, gif ye tack noought ta kepe ye fro it; Aw the dreggs o Rome mon be tane fro ye.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Gead feith, gif he tack yee in hand sir, y'ar aw hole.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Y'ar ta fat at hart sir, Pluraletes bred bet iddlenes, an iddlenes, bad humors; yee mon kepe a spar diet sir, an be brought lo wi Purgations sir, an whan tim sers ha sim Comfortives sir.

sp.speaker: Any.
sp.l: Sir, I shall trust my body to your Care.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Bet Ise net trust me saw to yours.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, Mr Soongul'd desires you would come with the Doctor to him presently.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: I sal swett hart, my Jo; Doctor, you mon ta Mr Soongul'd wi me.

sp.speaker: Any.
sp.l: You are sent for sir, I see.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Bet I sal ha ye in mind sir.

sp.speaker: Any.
sp.l: As soon as may bee—farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Fer noot sir, fer noot.

div.stage: Enter Trapheire, Witwud, and Townshift, Drawer with wine.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: This is the best Room Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Witw.
sp.l: It stinks of Tobacco, don't it Coz?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: How Tobacco!
Tobacco is Companion for a Prince.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I take none though.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then you want education; fill Boy, fill.
Townshift to thee.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Let it come.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, ther's some Gentlemen in the next Room desires your Company.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: I think their names be Drawforth and Pinckcarcase.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Plain Drawforth and Pinckcarcase; well admit e'm.
Shall it be so Coz?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I hope there'l be no quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What if there be?
Have you not here your men of Iron by you.
Can you be better back'd and brested sir;
Townshift, the Rogues have got a Bubble.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: The more the merrier—your servant,
Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: This is our friend, and desires your Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.l: Gentlemen, a man of worth, Ile assure you.

sp.speaker: VVit
sp.l: What Countrey man I pray sir?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: An Essex man sir, your servant.

sp.speaker: Drawf,
sp.l: The better flesh Ile warrant.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.l: I know not that sir, I have neer bin tri'd.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: Not neer shall be for me.

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.l: Drink, drink about.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: To thee Drawforth.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: A health to thy friends Mistris.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Well done, about with't.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: I thank you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: What! not begin another?

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: I've drank too hard allready; this same glass and no more:
Gentlemen, your Ladies health sir.

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.l: Why Traphiere, whence this gallantry?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What an idle question
Is that of thee; why, who should do't, but this?
He sent his Taylor to take measure of
The buildings of our bodies.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: And th' appurtenances
Came to us by like Providence.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Drink, drink about.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Coz, let me give thee o're our Wine some Counsell;
You are a landed Man, be carefull what
Strange Company you keep; for there are Cheats,
And desperate Cheates abroad, will make no Conscience
To bring you into Bonds, and make you sell
Or morgage all you have; take heed good Coz,
What Company you keep.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: He that cheats me, shall have good luck Coz.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: When does your Taylor fit your body with
A fashionable sute; this beares an Antique
And worn-out date. A gentleman of your Fortunes
And walk so like a Cow-driver.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.l: I will have one 'gainst Sunday.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: Some six yards makes me one too, let it be so; hah!

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: The like proportion fits me, twelve, us both.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.l: Well it shall be done Gentlte-men—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Drink, drink about, your friend is gone.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Ile send yours after him.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: I-must-be-gone, 'tis-late.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No sure. What, by thy Watch?

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: The hand is upp-on-on-twel-ve.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: A pretty Watch, I prethee lend it me,
To have another made by.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: Tis-a-Watch-of Price-Coz.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I would not borrow it else.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: What store of Chink have you?

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.l: Money-enough, mony-enough.

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.l: Lend me a peece or two.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.l: There-there Boy.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: The like to me sir, come, I shall, I shall.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.l: There-sir. Ile-be gon—

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.l: The house, the house, to pay.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Twenty two shillings and y'are welcome Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.p: make it up five and twenty, and you two shall cast Dice which payes it—are all parties agreed—I know [Exit. our noble friend will not be backward.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Nor ours; Heroick spirit wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Her's more wine Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: About with it, about with it.

sp.speaker: Drawf▪
sp.l: The Dice, the Dice.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Come tis a good throw Coz.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: But that's better sir; your friend paies.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: Hang him he cheated, he's a cheat.

sp.speaker: VVant
sp.l: Nere go not I, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: You lie, you lie.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: How the lie? will you take that?

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.l: How shall-I-help it pray?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Well done Coz.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: —Hang him he's-but a Country puppy Calfe.

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.l: Throw a Pot at's head.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.l: I shall-not-hit-him. If-I-doe; I am-no-more
Puppy-then your self—

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Why, that was well done.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: Ile-kick you sirrah—I learn'd-that of-you Coz—

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.l: Gallants expect to hear from us, and suddenly.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: A Coach there.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.l: I hope, they—wait—not for us—hah!

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What if they do? we fear em not, pay, pay;
Boy there's your reckoning. Call a Coach Boy.

sp.speaker: Scaref.
sp.p: Ha ye wark for a Scot Sawger, wha ha bien aw tha Wirld ore ons ten toes; Ser'd aw Religions, an can tha better be o eny. I ha kil'd tha Whar a Babilon, Body an Saw, brent aw her Rawlecks wi tha feer o zeale. I can carry twa feces under won hood: I can be a Sent, an I can be a Deel, gif ye ha wirk for me; I ha seeme a powre a riches in me dees, but ha broought noought heom wi me bet St Andras Cross, want an Poverty.

sp.speaker: Bill.
sp.p:
A sir! the bonny siller came a pece, gif I tol'd um a tale,
thay'd ga mickle heeds; geod feith won pell set'd aw malades.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: An whot pell wos thot mon?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: The Pell o sedition.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: A, ken you thot mon? tha sam set tha Magistrat an's wife intoll feares an jealousies, turn'd tha insid o tha Kirkmon ooutwards, an noow's aw gall, tha Ceteson gis as bitter; tha Leyer cannot stond he's brought sa weeke wy me Purgations, and tha Curtier noot worth tha grond a goes on; I ha let aw his geod as weele as he's bad bleod oout.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Saw ye Gentlemen gif ye ha a mind ta bien saw'd, ken ye me sirs?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: How sud we ken thee mon?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Wha, noot Scarefool your Contremon?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Whar hast bien mon?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Aw tha Wirld ore sirs, an noow aw pleces are wary o me; Ise cam ta Anglond toll seeke wirke.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Here's wirke enoough gif ye bien wise ta deele wy tha Anglish mon.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Geod feith Ise chet'um thay wern ner sa cheted, show me toll'um, whar liew thay?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: In th' Cety, and Contre ta; marry, bet cam awey wy us mon, wees tack a drinck first, an tawke mere on't.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Cam awey Io, cam awey.

div.head: ACT. IV.
div.stage: Enter Soonegul'd, and his Wife Layme down.

sp.speaker: Soon.
sp.l: DOwn with this Babell-builder, this Court pride,
Dagon and his Idolaters shall down.

sp.speaker: Lay.
sp.p: I, down with'em husband, down with 'em, they have stood long enough; I am sure their long standing have made you come short many a time and often, but I hope now husband you'l take 'em down a Button hole lower.

sp.speaker: Soon.
sp.p: Am not I a man?

sp.speaker: Lay.
sp.p: You think so husband, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Soon.
sp.p: Why, a King's no more.

sp.speaker: Lay.
sp.p: Nay, is he that husband? troth I dare say our man William is as good a man as the best of you; for as they say, a man is a man and he has but a hose on's head.

sp.speaker: Soor.
sp.p: Well, I am resolv'd William shall forth.

sp.speaker: Lay.
sp.p: Forth, how do you meane forth? I hope you will not leave me unprovided at home; you know your own business abroad, and I am certaine he can do your business at home better than your self— oh husbund, husband here's the Scotch Doctor.

sp.speaker: Soon.
sp.p: Mr Doctor, what news Mr Doctor?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Nen geod sir, nen geod sir, bet me frond ha had hes cass pul'd ore his lugs.

sp.speaker: Soon.
sp.p: By whom, by whom?

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Wha, wha, bet tha prod Prelates sir; Ise tolld 'um o thair knavery, an thay gar tack awey me brawery; bet thoough thay ha tacken awey me Cot, thay sall ner ta • k awey me conscience, that's holl an sound, an ned nen o thair pachings o thair preachments.

sp.speaker: Lay.
sp.p: O wicked, wicked children of darkness!

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Her's a frond o min sir, a mon a meight an mettell, wha ha endured meny a brunt and storme, he sall stond betwixt ye in aw harme.

sp.speaker: Soon.
sp.p: I shall be glad of your acquaintance sir.

sp.speaker: Lay.
sp.p: True, truly sir, you have a face like a man, you'l do the business I warrant, let you alone, but gently to the women sir, for we are twigs, and may be bow'd which way you list; meere tender twigs sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Bred, bet sam o ye bien toough enoough.

sp.speaker: Lay.
sp.p: We are a long time indeed a bringing up, but then we are soone cast downe; women have tender hearts, and tender flesh, and tender consciences, though naughty men report that we have none; husband shall they walk into th'Parlor; I do love to enter into Dialogue with these Gentlemen, they talke so prettily.

sp.speaker: Soon.
sp.p: I, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Lay.
sp.p: You will meet with sir fine Plunder 'mong the Ladies; you shall dine with us too—you may make me amends with a Court smock; I look to weare one in truth, they are so fine and so perfum'd, it passes.

sp.speaker: Soon.
sp.l: Come sir, wee'l discourse of our affaires
After w'ave din'd—you'l dine with us too Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Wees tack ye ot yar word.

div.stage: Enter Anything, and Boyes following him.

sp.speaker: Any.
sp.p: Nay, you may do't sirs, you may do't, you have warrant for't; 'tis well enough known, the Pompe of the Prelates, the Whore of Babylon her selfe in her feathers, the Kings of the earth commit fornication with her Plu • alities of Benefices makes men but idle, saies Mr Doctor, and idleness makes you fat, and fat makes you pursy, and so by consequence short winded; It is a trick of Rome to starve our Religion; Let Iezabell be brought before the Elders, and the whore of Babyilon to the Whipping post, let her have lash upon lash; let her smock be given to the Rag-men, it may come to be Paper, and her Condemnation writ in't; let the Whelpes and the Cubs be brought to the Stake, baite'um, baite'um, baite'um, I am your warrant saith Mr Doctor.

sp.speaker: Boyes.
sp.p: Master Doctor's an Ass.

sp.speaker: Any.
sp.p: Children you talk not like men, you are but midling Christians, 'tis well known to the Parish.

sp.speaker: Boyes.
sp.p: That Bedlams fit for you.

sp.speaker: Any.
sp.p: Those that will follow me, let 'um follow me,

l.hi: I am now for the Truth,

sp.speaker: Boyes.
sp.p: Hi, hi, hi, Stow the Frier, stow the Frier.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.l: You see what he has brought me to, my Crutches;
I was ere held an able man you know;
Had my tongue at Command, and my head too,
But now they both are so enfeebled I
Have scarce the use of either; if I had
It were all one, the Countrey People are
Bewitcht into beliefe, they have as much
Reason and Law as I, and will become
Their own Sollicitors, and Councell too.
I cannot last long, but expect still when
My Crutches will deceive me, and I fall
To th' ground for ever.

sp.speaker: Worn.
sp.l: —I am brought to nothing
Aswell as you, I little thought a Scotchman
Could ere have dreind my Veins, and purse so dry,
I am not worth the ground I go on; so
Dejected are my thoughts; my spirit lost,
And all the hopes of my recovery
Extinct and buried.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.l: I should not have known you,
Had you not told me who you were; you are
So changed from your self. Oh those were times,
Worthy to call to mind, (though to our griefe)
When you and I, like Twins, deriv'd a being
From one anothers sustenance, the Monopolies
That you projected, and I perfected!
Like two expert Limners, the one imploy'd
To fashion th' face, the other to finish it.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: —I, those were times indeed, but all I got
Then, has been since consumed; and I guess
You are not much the better; I am weary
I protest of my life, and would thank him
Would do me so much good as take it from me.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: —Patience is the best remedy where no
Better can be obtain'd; 'tis vaine to crave
The thing we want when 'tis not to be had;
Your dancing daies are done, and all the breath
The Scot has left me scarce will heat my fingers.

sp.speaker: Worn.
sp.l: —And my affliction does the more increase
To see my friends disabl'd, as I am,
From helping one another, 'tis a griefe
That's inexpressible, and not for cure.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.l: —What Fortune sowres, content must sweeten, he
Is the best man o'rcomes his misery.

div.stage: Enter Small faith and his wife.

sp.speaker: Smal.
sp.p:
—For my part, I am but a man, and I owe but a death,
let them take it, as they say they will, give 'um good on't, let them come, let them come—where are they? stand, stand, stand.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Husband now you talk of standing, pray let me lye down, and then let 'em do their worst, I defie 'em.

sp.speaker: Smal.
sp.p: —And so do I, wee'l to the Terret, Woman, and there we are secur'd 'gainst Devill, and Pursevant.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: —I'm weary'd off my legs with doing nothing but running up and down in e'ry Nooke and Corner like a Rat for feare of catching.

sp.speaker: Smal.
sp.p: —They are comming, they are comming; let me come in woman, let me come in.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would you would come in husband once, you have been out long enough to small purpose I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Res.
sp.l: Beleeve it, their Design aimes at our ruine;
And though the Cord they make be somewhat finer
Than Ordinary, 'Twill choak us at the last;
I hold a naked freedome better far
Than an adorned Prison; golden fetters
And Iron ones produce a like effect,
What differs them's but curiosity.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: Into what a Lethargy has these rabble Scots
Betray'd the peoples senses? tell them on't
And they'l abuse you for't. Nay, though they see
Distraction brought unto their very doores,
They'l look on't, and not know it till they feele it,
And then will tamely kiss the Rod that whipt 'em.
A Nation proud and Arrogant as the Beggar,
That when h'as got a Bonnet 'bove his wearing,
Will scarce bow to the Giver. All the service
They ever did this Nation was to help
The people eat their victuals, and share their fortunes.

sp.speaker: Res.
sp.l: Th'are good for nought, but to eat, louze, and sleep,
And stinck a street up. Tell you stories of
Don Iohn of Austria, the Magull, great Cham,
Their valour at Madril, Levant, or where
You will, and this in some blind Chimney Corner
In fume and smoake, rouz'd up with lanted Ale,
'Till that their faces do resemble th' Towns
They set on fire; And yet dare not encounter
A Rat or Weesell.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: —Yet the world reports
Them, men for siege the best, and can endure
The greatest hardship.

sp.speaker: Reso.
sp.l: Very true, if they
May but ly still they'l feed on one another,
Rather than venture on their Enemy
To get the least Provision, and indeed
The worst will serve their turne, for they are men
Loves any thing but beating, yet they'l take
That too if need be; take'em down a little,
And you may fillip dead a score of them.
It is a shame the English should become
Such mules to such base burdens; I'm resolv'd
To turne the Chance o'th'Dy that favours them,
Though to the hazard of my being.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: —'Twill
Be tane a peece of service fit for Chronicle,
And you shall want no furtherance.

sp.speaker: Reso.
sp.l: If I bring not
The Souldier, Doctors, and their Crue of Cheaters
As tamely to be hang'd as puppy Dogs,
Let me recelve no credit from you after.

div.stage: Enter Soonegul'd and a Seminary Priest going to weigh the Covenant with the Popes Bull.

sp.speaker: Soon.
sp.l: Sir, though I hate your Bulls, and your Decoyes,
And know you have two ends to all your waies;
I feare you not, for Truth will shew her selfe
Inspight of all the clouds you cast upon her.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: You are in th'right. Truth will appeare, and that
To th'shame of your trim'd Covenant; for though
She be but plaine, she is more glorious
Than all the gloss and Colours that sets forth
That new devise, Created to deceive
Poore simple people, and at last your selves.

sp.speaker: Soon.
sp.l: These are but bandying, Ile pursue my wager.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Ile venture ten pound more y'are lost in weight.

sp.speaker: Soon.
sp.l: You'l lose your selfe sir with your confidence.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Bar treachery and I care not.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I cannot endure this fighting Coz, a Dad.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Pox take your Dad; is that an Oath for a Gentleman?
A Lad at ten sweares more profoundly; you'l
Be quarrelling, and then you dare not fight;
As though I were a wall of Steele or Brass,
To stand betwixt you, and receive the Darts
Cast at you; Sir, why did your Cowship send
An Answer to your Challenge, if you found
Your bloud so Coole and Phlegmatick?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: 'Twas your doing,—I had not had the heart else.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: For preservation of your honour sir
Could you do less than Answer him?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What was he
That brought the Challenge?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Pinckcarcase by name.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A devillish name, and full of devillish ends;
This fighting is not lawfull; prethee Coz
Take up the matter, I have little maw to't.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: What, now the Hostage Reputation
Is past, will you Recant, Reneage, Revoke,
Recoyle, Revert? stand to your Principles.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I shall not stand an inch of ground beleeve me.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'Tis pitty th'art worth any; let me see,
How shall we do't with Honour?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: 'Tis no matter
For that thing Honour; let her walk alone,
I don't desire her Company on such tearmes,
Sweet Coz, sweet Coz.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Let me see—I'm resolv'd
That you shall fight him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Coz, I had forgot
I sweare, a strange infirmity, that is
I zound when as I heare a Gun shot off▪
And tremble at a Pistols, all my senses
Become as uselesse.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Why, 'twas your own motion.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: No matter, 'tis but so much charges lost,
I will not fight with Bullets, I've more conscience.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Why, then you must prepare a Case of Rapiers,
For Townshift and my selfe, ours are grown dull
With often usage.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Oh, the better Coz!
They'l do less mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then your fencing Master
Must make you at your Chamber fit for th' field.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: That's past his skill I'm sure; more charges Coz.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: It cannot be avoided, if you mean
To fight on foot, and put off your Horse combate.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: In my mind 'tis horse-play to fight on foot;
But hark you Coz, don't you make winking at
That Weapon ye call sharp, I'm not so set.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Fye, winking, No, how will you see to hit him;

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: No matter so he hit not me; but mayn't I
Bar Points being the Challenged?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That's base, and Player-like.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I'de rather play so, than worke otherwise.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Come, come, resolve, you know the time draws neere.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I would it did not, I love not to think on't;
Can we throw nothing in Times-way to make
Him stumble, and stop a little.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Resolve upon your weapon ere he be
Furnish'd with horse and Pistols.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Ile lay my life he's that already, then
'Twill be unworthy in you to—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p:
Good sir, talk not to me of Worthies, my Father was none of the Nine; he ne'r kept Company with your Huffs, nor Puffs; be
could drinke in a Taverne and ne're quarrell about the Reckoning; he liv'd without knocks, and dy'd in the love of his Parish.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: But he has left a quarrelsome son behind
Must pay for all.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I sha'n't stand much upon
That point, so I may be discharg'd from beatings;
Methinks a skin set out with Eylet holes
Appeares not handsome, nor a face to be
Painted with black and blew, I hate those colours.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: What will you give him shall take up the business without loss to your honour?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A man cannot lose
That which he never had; My Father was
A man of Bags, and might have been a Knight
When Knighthoods went a begging.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: But to the matter,
What say you to my proposition?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Troth,
It sounds well, let me see now what in Conscience
You will demand?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: But twenty peeces.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: So;
To save a man from beating, very good I
How many such d'ye meet with in the yeare?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Hundreds, hundreds sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Men must live Coz, men must live.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Any where but on me (good Coz;) but sir,
Before my Coz here, Ile give you ten.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Ten is too little in all conscience Coz.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Consider sir the danger.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And the Charge
Already I've been for horse and Pistols;
But those I hope you will return me, when
The peace is made.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Not one, expect not one,
Th'are forfeit Goods to us Lords of the Soile.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: 'Tis true, y'ave been at charges, and for that
Reason Ile undertake it at your rate;
Forbib, but I should beare a Conscience too.
Meet us at th' Mairmaid.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: At the houre of twelve.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: The precise time.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Cozen, he will deserve it.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Would I had his Art
To live by when I and my fortunes part.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: He is the Challenged, and justly may
Designe the way of fighting, and the Place;
But though you have provided us with Horses,
Swords, Pistols, and so forth, yet there's a thing
Cal'd money, we do want, put case he should
Fall by your hand, in what a case were we?

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Suppose that you should fail;
—I, there's the Danger.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: We must fly for't, and that we cannot do
Conveniently, without a sum, the Oratory
Of Silver makes our passage free and safe,
The want of it detaines us; open, open
Your close-mouth'd bags, and let them speake to us.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: Troth Gentlemen, Ile tell you, and I lie not,
Th'ave got a hoarsenesse since they came to Town,
And speak so low, a man can hardly heare 'em.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: One Mortgage sir will raise their voice againe.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: Well, well, he might have ta'ne another way
To worke; had I been he, and he been me,
I would have askt him Mercy.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: But you see
He is a man of spirit, spirit, sir!

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: I would he had no more then I, a gnat
Is better furnisht; I have heard my Mother
Protest, and solemnly, I had a heart
No bigger than a hazell Nut.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: —Why, saw she't?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: No, but she felt it; 'tis an imperfection
In Nature I can't help, and 'tis as cold
I warrant as a Cucumber.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: And riseth
So little in your stomack!

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: Troth, as little
As may be sir; how shall I heat it Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Drink wine and Drab.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: Why, so I do you know;
Yet when the flame of drinking's o'r, I fall
Into the Noose of Taverns, like a Pigeon.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: Only then y'ad best fight when y'are drunke.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: And so.
Be hang'd when I am sober; no, I beare
Too great a Conscience.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: If it be a burthen
Too hard to beare, wee'l teach you how to throw
It off, and live as we do without any.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: Take up this quarrell Gentlemen, and have
My heart for ever.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: What to do, to throw
The hounds ye starve? yet that so little, 'twill
Not be a mouthfull; 'tis your money we
Value the most, let your heart go as't came.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: Why, I shall mortgage next weeke.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: Are you serious?
May we give credit to you?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: I've occasion.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Thou shalt have more rather than want; my Buliy,
We are thy Guardians, who assaults our ward
Suffers, unlesse he be on a sure Guard.

div.head: ACT. V.

sp.speaker: Billy.
sp.p:
BRed, thos Anglish ar Deeles, w'are aw lost men; Aw oour knavery is oout, nen wull tack oour parts; Tha Ceteson •
hong thare heds doown lick bull rushes, an won noot bien sen for us.

sp.speaker: Iock.
sp.p: Hoow cam thay in tha Deeles namsa aw o won mind? Ise sur Ise ded whot Ise cud toll mack 'um • et on oder ta deeth; tha Deele feere 'um, thar lick Serpans that gif ye smit 'um asunder wull joyne agen.

div.stage: Enter Scarefoole with his sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: W'are aw lost, sheft, sheft, tha Deeles a comming toll tare tha Covnant sha yeer heeles, sha yeere heeles, spang awey sirs, spang awey.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: On's gif tha men o War flee, what sall we hid our sells— Aw sir; sir.

sp.speaker: Reso.
sp.p: Take them into your Custody, they are Your lawfull prize.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: A sirs, a sirs, geod feith wees ment ne bad.

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.p: What Mr Doctors! have we found ye? who can cure the Citizen of his head ach but the Scotch Doctors? who their wives of the Tooth-ach but the Scotch Doctors? the Scotch Doctor is all in all, the Kirke will take no Physick but of the Scotch Doctor; the Country will be cheated by none but by the Scotch Doctor; the Court and Gentry will be begger'd by none but the beggerly Scotch Doctors; come away and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Ioc. Bil.
sp.p: Mercy sirs, Mercy, Mercy, Mercy.

div.stage: Enter Scarefoole running with his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Hawd, hawd, hawd sir.

sp.speaker: Resolu.
sp.l: Nay, I don't intend
To take th' advantage of you as I may,
I owe a greater honour to true valour;
I have heard Nobly of your Countrymen,
And therefore to assure my selfe Report
Lies not, I have expos'd my Person to
This single hazard.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: A sir▪ I dee leov you.

sp.speaker: Resol.
sp.l: And I shall love you too, if that I find
You prove as Gallant as y'ave spoke your selfe:
Consider what dependances are on you,
Whom y'ave involv'd by your large promises
To this Engagement; let them see you dare
Do something for their money.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Be me saw sir
sp.p: Y'are a mickle Gallant mon, Ise thra me swerd an hert at your non feet sir.

sp.speaker: Resol.
sp.l: That's base, not Souldierlike; submissiveness
In this Case speakes you Coward, and if so,
My breath has been ill spent; what, will you fight?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Noot a neustye sir, geod feith I leove a Anglish mon wy aw my hert. A sir, A sir, send aw reight, send aw reight—her tack me weppon, Ise your non Prisoner sir geod feith.

sp.speaker: Resol.
sp.l: Since thou art so base,
And not fit for a Noble Treaty, take
This, this, and this.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: A geod sir, use me like a Gentlmen.

sp.speaker: Resol.
sp.l: A Gentleman, a Swineheard, hangye, go,
The Bubbles broke, the wind gave Being to.
Y'are welcome Gentlemen, shew a Roome there Boy.

div.stage: Enter Trapheire, Witwud, Townshift, and Drawer.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Sirrah, there will some Gentlemen aske for us,
Direct 'em hither.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: I shall sir; what's your wine?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Sack, Boy, the quickning sack; and such Tobacco
As may inspire a spirit into clay,
Quick, and as sharpe as lightning.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Oh good sir,
I can't endure to think upon a storme;
Talk not of lightning, it does bode some quarrelling;
The calmest language is the best, when there's
A peace intended.

div.stage: [Enter Drawforth, Pinckcarcase, Wantwit, and Drawer with wine.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Here they come; now Coz
For your honour seeme somewhat averse
To an agreement; carry your selfe stoutly,
With an unalter'd Countenance.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: 'Tis not in
The power of humane frailty.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: —Gallants, welcome;
Y'are men I see for Credit.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: What must I say?

sp.speaker: Drawf
sp.l: Carry your selfe manly.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: What would I give now for an Inch of manhood;
How he does eye me; would I had a look
But halfe so piercing, I'de encounter then
With Basilisks; It carries daggers in't
Will penetrate a Coat of Male; there is
sp.stage: [Witwud and Wantwit stare at one another.
sp.l: No safety but in distance.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: How he looks at me!
With such a hungry countenance, as though
He meant to satisfie himselfe upon me;
