But if he knew but what a peece of flesh
He had to deale with, hee'd not be so greedy;
I was not cut out for a Royster; sure
Nature ne'r meant me for the field, unless
To call my Cattle home, or try my hounds.
I am so great an enemy to a sword
I weare none when I ride; Oh, how yon fellow
Would spurne me, like a Mushrome, could he get
Me but alone; but he shall be hang'd first.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What, all this while and speake not to each other?
Why, you have hearts of Oake: Not bow, deare Coz!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Come, we must have you friends.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: With all my heart sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: How's this? the man's bewitcht;
See what the Gold can doe!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: If you please sir, I am your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And what say you Coz?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Hum, I smelt, 'tis so,
The fellow is a Coward on my life.
Are they not all so? 'tis a blessing then.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Come sir, our friend is willing to passe by
All the affronts you gave him, if you'l wave
His Challenge.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Ile wave nothing but my Sword
Against my Enemy.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Shall we be friends?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A friendly bloūd runs not yet currant in me;
Be challenged by a dunghill Cock? I scorne it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Why, this is rare! Coz, Ile spit in thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis your friends desire aswell as ours
To prevent bloudshed.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: —Let such things as you,
That dare not waste their bloud be sparing on't;
For my part, Ile not value if he Tap
From me a Pailefull.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Who the Devill Conjur'd
Up such a spirit in him?

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: Your friend's grown—
Take him down, or by this light
Ile kick him.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Pough, let me alone for that.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: The Gentleman grows angry, Ile be gon.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Hang him, a Coward, a meere Coward, friend▪

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: How, a coward! he speakes not like one;
I would his hands were ty'd behind him, I
Would make a triall on't; but he has teeth
Strong as the tusks of Boares, and legs more stiff
And big then any Bedspost, I should do
no good upon him.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Come Coz, throw
Your Ranting habit off, the Scene of War
Is past, and now put on your Robe of Amity,
The Bride-garment of Peace.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: —Peace! who shall peace?
'Tis sawciness to tell me so.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: How's this!
You worme! 'slight, if I lay my hands
Upon you once, Ile teare you into nothing▪
You Cowardly simple Puppy. Sirra, Ile—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Not so loud good Coz;
You know I have but follow'd your directions.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Be hang'd, and overdone it, ha'n't you sirrah?
The Gentlemen shall know you have not spirit
To look a Cat in th'face, if that you ben't
More sociable.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: —Good Cozen, Ile do any thing.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Well, I have brought him to't with much adoe;
Here, shake hands, sir; you must be friends.

div.stage: by the hand and brings him to Witwud.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Well, if I must, I must, patience is a vertue,
And Ile embrace it—I am your friend sir.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: I shall never be your foe sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: So said, and so done sir, will do well.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: The Rascall acts it handsomly.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: To your credit:
Ours is the silliest Rogue.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Boy, more wine;
Would we had Musicke here to celebrate
This Nuptiall.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: I will send for some.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Do so; come, here's to the Married Couple.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I do beleeve we both can't got a Boy
Will prove a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: Ah sirrah, are you there?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I am your own man sin.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: Let's have a good Ayre, but drink first.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Drinke about Gallants, what the Musick duls you;
Hast e're a new song fellow?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Yes, of the Scots comming into England.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That, that by all meanes.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Please you to heare me—'tis but a Ballad put to
One of their own tunes.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: The better, the better, let's hear't.

lg.l: CAm lend, lend y'ar lugs Ioes, an Ise speeke a song,
Sing he heom agen Iocky, sing heom agen Iocky.
O hes bonny deeds, an hes prowes emong;
Sing heom agen, heom agen, O valent Iocky.
Sirs Iocky's a Mon held o mickle Note,
Sing heom agen▪ Iocky, &c.
The breech o tha Covnant stuck in hes throte;
Sing heom agen, heom agen, &c.
For Iocky wes riteous, whilke ye wad admire;
Sing heom agen, &c.
He fooght for the Kirke, bet a plunder'd tha Quire;
Sing heom agen, heom agen, &c.
An Iocky waxt roth an toll Anglond a cam,
Sing heom agen, &c.
Ero whance he'd returne, bet a lack a is Lam;
Sing heom agen, &c.
An Iocky wes armed fro top toll toe,
Sing heom agen, &c.
Wia powre o Men, anth' are geod Deuke I tro;
Sing heom agen, &c.
Sa valent I wis thay wer, an sa prat,
Sing heom agen Iocky; &c.
Ne cock nor hen durst stond in their gat;
Sing heom agen, heom, &c.
In every streete thay ded sa flutter,
Sing heom agen, &c.
Ne Child dorst shaw hes bred an butter;
Sing heom agen, &c.
Noow whan oour ferces thay herd on o're night,
Sing heom agen, &c.
Next morne they harnest themsels for a fight;
Sing heom agen, &c.
Thare Deuke was tha mon that wad be sen stoote,
Sing heom agen &c.
Sing heom agen, &c.
Our men that ater these valent Scot went,
Sing heom agen, &c.
Had ner fond him oout bet by a strong sent.
Sing heom agen heom agen, o valent Iocky.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha! it's good enough for the subject,

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: Drinke about, drinke about; More wine Boy;
Here Witwud to thee.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Let's discharge the Musick.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: There ye Rascals.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Thanke you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: Trapheire to thee.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Let it come, a Pint and thou darst.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: Art mad, Trapheire is drunke enough, hee'l be
Not'company for a Dog immediately.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: To your Mightiness sir.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: I shall pledge your Highness sir—to you sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Excuse me pray sir, I am almost spent.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: Not pledge me!

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No, he shall not pledge you sir;
What then? he is my friend.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: But why should he
Be more excus'd then ours? will you drinke for him?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Not, neither sir.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: Then he shall pledge me sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: He shall not sir.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Nay Trapheire, what dost meane?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Hang him turd—Are you good at that sir?
I shall returne you Answer by this Messenger.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Good Coz no fighting; I will drink a Gallon
Rather than lose one drop of bloud—It is
Too pretious for the floore to drinke.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Gentlemen your noise has drawn Souldiers into the house, th'a • e comming up; as many as can get into that little Closet,

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.l: I would not be in custody for a Million;
The Rode, the Rode—

div.stage: [Tra. Pinc. Town, and Drawf. yet in.

sp.speaker: Drawf.
sp.l: That's all our faults, in, in.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Where shall we be?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.p: Where's all these Huffs—what you two make this noise? hurle Pots, breake Glasses, you are youths indeed; Is this a time of night for you to rant in? come you must with us.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.l: Nay good Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you may come forth, the coast is cleare.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Where's the two Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: They have ta'ne 'em with 'em.

sp.speaker: Pinc
sp.p: Did they pay the Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: A pox upon you, why did you not aske'em for't?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I durst not sir, for feare they should say, the rest of their Company was above.

sp.speaker: Pinc.
sp.p: 'Tis right, the Devil's on't, this was your doing Trapheire, Will you pay the Reckoning now?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Not a penny, Ile keepe unto my Oath, throw who shall dip or pay if you will.

sp.speaker: Pinck.
sp.p: Here's Dice, throw—twelve, hang ye Rascall [Pinc. thro. Now my Chance—'tis passable—throw.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Mine is the worst.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: But mine's the worst of all—Sirrah Boy will you take this Cloake for your Reckoning?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I know not sir whether I shall or not.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You shall not sir, now, you know, as long as such Spankers last; what's to pay?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: But thirty shillings sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Death! but thirty saiest thou? well, there 'tis;
I shall be even with some body.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.l: Why, this was handsome Trapheire.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Make roome for the Magistrates;
The Prisoners
sp.stage: Enter Do-much, Surebold, Resolution, Scarefoole, Iocky, Billy, Smallfaith, and his Wife, Soonegul'd and his Wife, Anything, Downfall, Worn-out, Seminary, Publique Notary.
sp.l: There—

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Which are
The Prisoners?

sp.speaker: Resol.
sp.l: These sir.

sp.speaker: Ioc. Bil.
sp.l: Mercy, mercy, Master Judge.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: What are those?

sp.speaker: Resol.
sp.p: The subjects on the which these Villaines practis'd their subtilties and deceits; first, I shall tender my Charge against 'em, then produce my evidence.

sp.speaker: Doe.
sp.l: Very well, very well, proceed.

sp.speaker: Resol.
sp.l: In briefe (Sir) then they have infected most
Part of this Nation; here's a thing,
A man of Reputation once, and bore
A place amongst you.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: I do pitty him.

sp.speaker: Resol.
sp.l: And now is fit for no place except Bedlam:
Here is another, a man you would think
The Devill could not worke upon, and yet
These Scotch ones have. The Lawyer, father of
Contrivances, is noos'd in one himselfe;
He cannot stand without his Crutches, and
His head's so light his nose is every minute
Ready to touch the ground.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: What is that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Resol.
sp.l: Do you conceive him one? have they left ought
Upon him like a Creature? may we sweare
He is a perfect man, no Ghost? 'tis hard.
The hurryings he has had with sleepless eyes,
Continuall Purgations, Bleedings, what not,
That they could but invent to bring him low;
He's all's left of a Courtier, and deserves
Your pitty; there's no double doores betwixt
His heart now, and your eyes; he's so transparent
You may see through him. Tis not these alone
Th'ave brought to this, but all the Country people,
Both Common sort, and Gentry.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: What say you for yourselves?

sp.speaker: Ioc. Bil.
sp.p: Mercy, mercy, mercy, wees leove tha Anglish mickle weele.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: Yes, it appeares so; weele requite your Loves,
But cannot say, with your own Coyne, because
You never were worth any, but wee'le find
A way to pay you home.

sp.speaker: Resol.
sp.l: When they had thus
Spread their infection, they begin to thinke
Their safety would not last without the Souldier;
And to that end and purpose does perswade
The giddy People, which they had before
Distemper'd, with their Poysons, to receive
This man of Feather, as their grand Protector:
They take him, and to Covenant they go;
Two hundred thousand pounds! (a sum would buy
Their Kingdome) must be raised and paid to them.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Very fine.

sp.speaker: Resol.
sp.l: But marke sir the event,
I am resolv'd to open what they did
For all this Money.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: 'Twill do well indeed.

sp.speaker: Resol.
sp.l: They gave a peece of Paper, in the which
Were strange things promis'd then, As if that all
The Courage of the world contracted were
In their, and but their Nation.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: And what found you?

sp.speaker: Reso.
sp.l: I now proceed to that; I found'um sir,
Like Bull-rushes, that tremble if the wind
But blow on them, they run and tumbl'd o're
The necks of one another, like to tiles
A storme forces from houses tops; this any thing
But man, who own'd the name of their Protector,
In the most abject'st manner, and beneath,
The Spirit of a man, threw at my feet.
His Sword, and himselfe too, on single tearmes,
Without a stroke; Scarefoole they call him, and
They must be Citizens or none that feare him;
A Rat shall make him run to his own Country.

sp.speaker: Scare.
sp.l: Ise a Gentlemon sir, mind ye me? Ise gange toll me non
Contre wy aw me hert gif ye wul.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: Not in such haste sir, wee'l reserve you for
Another purpose—take him hence to prison.

sp.speaker: Scare.
sp.l: The faw Deele fier thot tong.

sp.speaker: Reso.
sp.l: What thinke you sir that Paper, cost so much,
Is worth in weight? here's one will tell you sir.

sp.speaker: Pub. No.
sp.l: I am a publike Notary by profession,
And dare speake nothing but the truth; the wager
Past on this Gentlemans side, the Popes Bull weighed,
It down by much, the other was not worth
In weight a Penny loafe.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: But what make you here sir?

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Not to do harme sir.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Stay not here upon
Your perill sir, your Bulls have too long tailes.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: I stay but for a winde sir.

sp.speaker: Soon.
sp.l: I must confess we have been much deluded,
Cheated, and Cozen'd by these perjur'd Scots,
Under the shew of zeale and honesty.

sp.speaker: Lay.
sp.p: Hang 'em Rogues, they complaine they are pillaged, you made 'em not bare enough sirs, you should have taken their skins off too, they would have made monsters of us, but truly my husband is a Naturall man, and I am his own wife; I hope you do not thinke we are otherwise than we should be.

sp.speaker: Mrs Smal.
sp.p:
I have a husband here too, helpe his head, he was a Man once, and I was a Woman, as this Gentleman the Courtier knew well enough, but now I am no-body, thanke yo • pick-purses;
Pray spare 'em not, I'm sure they would not spare me when time was, do what I could.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: Take them hence, there will be order shortly
To pack 'em to some forraigne parts, they are
But Caterpillers, and what place soe're
They come at will be th' worse for't; take 'em hence.

sp.speaker: Ioc. Bil.
sp.l: A mercy, mercy, mercy.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: You have done Justice.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: Y'ave seene these Scots desected, Gentlemen,
And what d' you find 'em now to be, but Rascals?
Meere Mountebanks, that has instead of Cure
Bred strange Diseases, and distempers 'mongst you;
Juglers, that look'd you in the face, and told
You a fine tale, to keepe your senses busie,
While they did pick your Pockets.

sp.speaker: Lay.
sp.l: Our Pockets say you sir? I, and something else too, could
They have come at it; but soft, soft, two words to a bargain.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: Master Smallfaith, we shall do what lies in us,
Upon your Recantation, to bring
You into favour with the Common Wealth,
And seat you as before, as Capable
Of her Preferment.

sp.speaker: Smal.
sp.l: I thanke you.

sp.speaker: His Wife.
sp.l: Blessing on your hearts.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: We make the same profession sir to you,
On the like tearmes. You may do much
Upon the giddy People, by th' example
Of your own Reformation.

sp.speaker: Any.
sp.l: Sir, I shall
Do what befits an honest man (abus'd)
And servant to the Common Wealth.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: And you sir,
Are not exempted here the benefit
Of favour if you will take hold of it.

sp.speaker: Soone.
sp.l: I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Lay.
sp.p: I, and hold it fast husband; had I a good thing to handle, I'd make much on't a long time I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: As for these Gentlemen here, Master Downfall,
And Master Worn-out, we shall do our best
To set the one upon his legs agen;
And restore th' other, though not to his full
Ability, yet to a health contentable.

sp.speaker: Down. Worn.
sp.l: We are your servants.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: When all our minds and hearts are firmly knit,
Let the Scot do his worst, by Sword or Wit.
